This was superseded by #2474. @maysamyabandeh, maybe you can close this one? @resetius, if you could verify that #2474 fixes your issues that would be great. I added an integration test that should emulate both problematic scenarios, but additional verification is always good. Also, reviews from both of you are more than welcome.

@dguy 
 - I added extra test for `KStreamBuilder.addSource` with `TimestampExtract` arguments. Not sure it is much different from `TopologyBuilder.addSource` test.
- In `SourceNode` class, not all variables can be final as they are initialized in `init()` method.
- In `StreamTask` 121, the `SourceNode` was getting `null` if the source is defined with `Pattern`.   I deleted "Pattern [ ]" string from `SourceNode`name  (it was initialized like "Pattern [ " + regex + "]" )  so that I can compare with `topic` names.

@mjsax 
I could not get the reason to insert new overloaded methods further below. The next method below is the most generic one (with most arguments) which is 
```
public <K, V> KStream<K, V> stream(final AutoOffsetReset offsetReset,
                                       final TimestampExtractor timestampExtractor,
                                       final Serde<K> keySerde,
                                       final Serde<V> valSerde,
                                       final Pattern topicPattern) 
```

Test FAILed (JDK 8 and Scala 2.12).

I had a look at bunch of those failures. It looks like all `ProduceConsumeValidate` tests failed with 

```
[INFO  - 2017-01-31 14:30:45,817 - runner_client - log - lineno:221]: RunnerClient: kafkatest.tests.client.compression_test.CompressionTest.test_compressed_topic.compression_types=.snappy.gzip.lz4.none.new_consumer=False: Summary: Consumer failed to consume messages for 60s.
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/kafka/venv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/ducktape-0.6.0-py2.7.egg/ducktape/tests/runner_client.py", line 123, in run
    data = self.run_test()
  File "/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/kafka/venv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/ducktape-0.6.0-py2.7.egg/ducktape/tests/runner_client.py", line 176, in run_test
    return self.test_context.function(self.test)
  File "/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/kafka/venv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/ducktape-0.6.0-py2.7.egg/ducktape/mark/_mark.py", line 321, in wrapper
    return functools.partial(f, *args, **kwargs)(*w_args, **w_kwargs)
  File "/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/kafka/tests/kafkatest/tests/client/compression_test.py", line 84, in test_compressed_topic
    self.run_produce_consume_validate(lambda: wait_until(
  File "/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/kafka/tests/kafkatest/tests/produce_consume_validate.py", line 116, in run_produce_consume_validate
    self.start_producer_and_consumer()
  File "/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/kafka/tests/kafkatest/tests/produce_consume_validate.py", line 89, in start_producer_and_consumer
    self.consumer_start_timeout_sec)
  File "/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/kafka/venv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/ducktape-0.6.0-py2.7.egg/ducktape/utils/util.py", line 36, in wait_until
    raise TimeoutError(err_msg)
TimeoutError: Consumer failed to consume messages for 60s.
```

I will debug it, post a fix, and re-run the system tests.

Hmm, fair point, I missed that the old ones were preserved farther down. Is there a reason we're preserving all the old upgrade docs? It's just going to continue to grow indefinitely... Given that we have links to the old docs, is there any point to keeping any of the old ones around?
It's a good question. I am not sure. We could potentially just add a link to the previous version to make it convenient?
@lindong28, thanks for the PR. I probably won't have time to review before next week. cc @junrao as well since he reviewed the KIP.

So I dug into the failures a bit more. It appears that only those `ProduceConsumeValidate` tests which use the old consumer are failing with the error above. The interesting thing is that the consumer logs show that consumer does consume messages. 

But the actual output captured from the ssh command doesn't record anything. This was verified by running the code with this additional debug line: 

https://github.com/apurvam/kafka/commit/0444cf48503694c0f66364408f475a27a7938f09

I am not sure what about this patch would cause this kind of behavior.
@apurvam, the metric we are looking for only exists in the new consumer, so we have to make it conditional on that, I guess. And maybe look for the equivalent metric in the old consumer if it exists.

That's a good point. But that does  not seem related to the problem at hand. The check for assigned partitions and consumer liveness only if the `consumer_init_timeout_sec` is non zero. It is zero by default, and only the throttling tests set it to non zero. The compression test, etc., don't hit the code path in question, and still fail with this PR.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk8-scala2.11/1448/
Test PASSed (JDK 8 and Scala 2.11).

My latest patch to enable the partitions assignment check only for the new consumer has shown positive results -- previous tests like `compression_test` which used the old consumer passed with this patch.

I have re-run the system tests on the latest code: http://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/704/

If it passes, that is an excellent catch, @ijuma !

@junrao Already refined the value for 'queued.max.requests' from 16 to 500. And also removed the invalid config 'controller.message.queue.size'. I also deleted all config items for the flush things since we recommend user employ replication for durability and leave the task to the operating system's background flush capabilities. Does it make sense?
@ijuma What's the status for this PR? Any further discussion I had missed?
@ijuma What's the status for this PR? Do I address all your comments already?
